Over 5% of Canada‚Äôs oceans are now protected! We just reached and surpassed our national marine conservation target of protecting 5% of our marine and coastal areas by 2017 with the establishment of new marine refuges off the coast of British Columbia and Quebec. üåä

If you witness a fisheries violation, please report it. You can contact our department directly by calling the local Fisheries and Oceans Canada office in your area: http://ow.ly/3T6P30fLWWR  

In any province or territory you can also call Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-TIPS (8477) which is an anonymous service.

caption_original:
Small mussel, big problem. Did you know that Zebra Mussels are capable of heavily colonizing hard and soft surfaces like docks, boats and beaches? They can clog intake structures in power stations and water treatment plants and cause millions of dollars in damages. Zebra Mussels are found throughout all the Great Lakes. 

They are an average of 2-2.5 cm, reaching up to 4 cm long, triangular in shape, and are black or brown with white to yellow zigzagged patterns. If you think you‚Äôve seen or caught a Zebra Mussel where they are not known to occur:
*Do not release it into the water.
*Catch it and keep it frozen. If you can‚Äôt do that, destroy it.
*Note the location (with GPS coordinates if possible) as well as the observation date.
*Contact Fisheries and Oceans Canada: http://ow.ly/v6nI30fzR1P
Click here for more information about this Aquatic Invasive Species: http://ow.ly/XWGZ30fzR9Q

They are an average of -2.5 cm, reaching up to cm long, triangular in shape, and are black or brown with white to yellow zigzagged patterns. If you think you‚Äôve seen or caught a Zebra Mussel where they are not known to occur: *Do not release it into the water. *Catch it and keep it frozen. caption_original: Sea lampreys are parasitic, invasive pests in the Great Lakes. They attach to fish with their suckermouth; rasp away skin and flesh with their tongues and feed on the blood of their prey, eeeewww. On average, a single sea lamprey can destroy 18 kg (40 lbs) of fish in its lifetime. They are so destructive that, under some conditions, only one out of seven fish attacked will survive. We work closely with U.S partners to control this aquatic invasive species. Find out what you can do to help: http://ow.ly/DHpF30fzEpY Great Lakes Fishery Commission

On average, a single sea lamprey can destroy kg (40 lbs) of fish in its lifetime. They are so destructive that, under some conditions, only one out of seven fish attacked will survive. We work closely with U.S partners to control this aquatic invasive species. Find out what you can do to help: Great Lakes Fishery Commission

caption_original: Everything that empties into a storm drain eventually ends up in fish and wildlife habitat. Have you noticed yellow fish painted next to the storm drains on your street? caption_original:
After 12 North Atlantic Right Whale deaths this summer, and with today‚Äôs findings from the Canadian Wildlife Health Cooperative, we must do more to protect right whales for future generations. This report, prepared and released in partnership with the Marine Animal Response Society and Fisheries and Oceans Canada, is the result of many weeks of analysis, research and collaborative work by a devoted team of veterinarians, pathologists and scientists. We thank them for their commitment to this important task. Today‚Äôs findings confirm that the biggest threats to the right whale continue to be vessel strikes and entanglements. Over the next few months, we will meet with partners to plan for changes next summer aimed at helping protect right whales from further harm. http://ow.ly/TdMz30fFsFo 

University of Prince Edward Island

caption_original: Be on the lookout! Tench (or Tinca tinca) is a large, invasive species in the minnow family found in British Columbia and Quebec. Tench is not established in Ontario yet, but we should be watching out for it, especially in Lake Ontario. Its impact is unknown; however, where lots of Tench are found, they may affect the food chain. Click here to report sightings: http://ow.ly/G7uP30fUsuP

caption_original: Thanks to all who lent a hand during last month‚Äôs beach cleanup of Baynes Sound and Lambert Channel in British Columbia! In 5 days, 140 volunteers cleaned 6 beaches and removed more than 60 cubic metres of debris, much of it plastic. The cleanup was jointly organized by DFO, the Association for Denman Island Marine Stewards and the BC Shellfish Growers Association. Up to 90% of the material collected will be reused or recycled.

Canada has made advances in ocean protection, designating three new Marine Protected Areas in the Atlantic, Pacific, and Arctic oceans, identifying a new large Area of Interest off the coast of British Columbia, and proposing amendments to the Oceans Act, which will allow Canada to protect sensitive and important areas of our oceans, faster. 
At this year‚Äôs Our Ocean Conference, Minister LeBlanc shared Canada‚Äôs scientific criteria for establishing marine refuges and how Canada will explore ways to support and protect the Arctic Ocean‚Äôs ‚Äúlast ice area‚Äù where summer ice remains year round. More information on our efforts to meet our conservation targets here: http://ow.ly/JUd930fFKM1

caption_original:
If you‚Äôre a boater or fisher, it‚Äôs important to learn to identify Asian carp, an aquatic invasive species. 
The term, ‚ÄúAsian carp‚Äù actually refers to four species of carps. Black Carp have a blunt, scaleless head with a small toothless mouth, and no barbels. They have a pointed snout and a slightly downturned mouth. The body is long and narrow and the dorsal fin is shorter than that of Common Carp. Scales are very large with dark edges, giving a cross-hatched appearance. If you think you‚Äôve found a Black Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/QoOk30fUGLu

caption_original: Our scientists in Newfoundland and Labrador measured over 35,000 crab during the 2017 inshore crab monitoring program. Twelve scientists, led by biologist Darrell Mullowney, placed over 200 sets of crab pots in seven bays around Newfoundland, supported by Canadian Coast Guard‚Äôs CCGS Vladykov crew. Now scientists will use this data to examine recent changes in population structure and size during the 2017 snow crab assessment.

caption_original: If you are a boater or fisher, it‚Äôs important to learn to identify these aquatic invasive species. Bighead Carp have a very large head, a toothless mouth without barbels, and small scales. Their eyes are forward on their head and sit below the mouth. They are solid grey on the back, blending to white below, with dark blotches. If you think you‚Äôve found a Bighead Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/ZXnK30fLVLG

caption_original: Earlier this year, scientists from the Bedford Institute of Oceanography identified a new species of carnivorous sponge in Atlantic Canadian waters ü§©. A sample of the sponge was originally collected from the Flemish Cap on a mission in 2010, northeast of the Grand Banks at a depth of almost 3000 metres below the surface of the ocean. New discoveries like this highlight the importance of continuous research in our oceans from coast to coast to coast.

caption_original: We are making navigation safer in British Columbia by investing close to $20 million in hydrographic surveys. This will allow the Canadian Hydrographic Service to collect and share information on water levels, tides, and currents. We will also be able to produce high-resolution charts for mariners. Four B.C. ports have already been surveyed, and nine more will be completed, reducing the risk of accidents. https://t.co/2pbMVufbKR

Although some of the best geoduck clams in the world come from British Columbia, many locals have yet to taste this distinct-looking shellfish. This international delicacy is farmed commercially or harvested by divers who use high-pressure water delivered through a nozzle known as a "stinger" to lift the clams out alive.
Learn more about geoduck clams: http://ow.ly/l3ML30fzNl7

caption_original: Say ‚ÄúAaah‚Äù! Yes they‚Äôre big and look scary, but basking sharks are planktivores. They spend much of their time feeding on plankton and small crustaceans with their extremely large mouth and prominent gill rakers. This time of year, basking sharks migrate from the North to the South Coast of British Columbia. caption_original:
We are a proud partner in the Fundy Salmon Recovery project to protect and restore the Atlantic salmon population. Over 700 Inner Bay of Fundy Atlantic salmon are being transferred to rivers in Fundy National Park in New Brunswick to spawn after being raised in the world‚Äôs first Atlantic salmon marine conservation farm. Inner Bay Fundy Atlantic salmon are endangered and are protected under Canada‚Äôs Species at Risk Act.  It is illegal to kill, harm, harass, capture or take these Atlantic salmon.
http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/species-especes/profiles-profils/salmon-atl-saumon-eng.html

caption_original:
Learn to identify invasive species! 
Silver Carp is one of four species of invasive Asian carp and is best known for its startled response. You‚Äôve probably seen videos of them leaping as high as three metres above the water‚Äôs surface when disturbed by boat motors or other noise. 
Silver Carp have a large, scaleless head, and a toothless mouth without barbels. Closely related to Bighead Carp, Silver Carp tends to be narrower in shape. They are greyish-black on top and have small, curved scales. They can live up to 20 years!
If you think you‚Äôve found a Silver Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/LiTX30gdOcU

caption_original:
University of Victoria‚Äôs Ocean Networks Canada is receiving $7.2 million in new funding for oceanographic technology that will improve marine safety and protect Canada‚Äôs marine species, as part of the Oceans Protection Plan.
Digital hydrophone technology will measure underwater noise in key areas off the coast of British Columbia. The information collected includes the speed and direction of surface currents and waves, allowing us to predict the movements of debris, ships in distress, and oil spills over time. http://ow.ly/8inT30fOdZi

caption_original:
Did you know that lightships preceded lighthouses to help signal dangerous areas for navigation? From 1830 to 1960, about ten of these ships were used to provide safer navigation on the St. Lawrence River. They were anchored near obstacles where the construction of a lighthouse was impossible. In Quebec, the era of the lightships ended in 1963 and several of them were replaced by pillars.

See more photos: https://www.flickr.com/photos/mpo-dfo_quebec/sets/72157650880831352

caption_original:
Navigate safely through Canadian waterways with marine charts prepared for your area: http://ow.ly/EmxE30g7Aka. 

It‚Äôs the Canadian Hydrographic Service that prepares, publishes and updates these nautical charts as well as other nautical publications essential for the safety of maritime navigation of Canadian waterways. Our team does so much more! They collect and transmit information on tides and water levels, conduct hydrographic surveys to detect hazards to navigation and provide seabed mapping in support of scientists, as well as the fishing industry and engineering. Learn more about the work of the Canadian Hydrographic Service: https://youtu.be/igLllVNuFyo

caption_original: If you are a boater or a fisher, it‚Äôs important to learn to identify invasive species like Grass Carps. Grass Carp have a wide, scaleless head, toothless mouth, no barbels, and a very short snout. They are dark grey with lighter sides (white to yellow) that have a slightly golden shine. Their scales are large with dark edges, and their fins are clear to grey-brown. Adult Grass Carp mostly eat aquatic vegetation. If you think you‚Äôve found a Grass Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/sEyG30g4ft4
